def insertion_sort(arr):
    p = 0
    while p < len(arr):
        z = i
        while z > 0 and arr[z - 1] > arr[z]:
            temp = arr[z]
            arr[z] = arr[z - 1]
            arr[z - 1] = temp
            z -= 1
        p += 1
    return arr

def insertion_sort(arr):
    p = len(arr)
    while p > 0:
        z = i
        while z < len(arr) and arr[z - 1] > arr[z]:
            temp = arr[z]
            arr[z] = arr[z - 1]
            arr[z - 1] = temp
            z += 1
        p -= 1
    return arr

"There seems to be a mistake in the provided code snippet. The variable `i` is used but not defined within the function. Assuming that `i` should be the loop variable that starts from `0` and goes up to `len(arr) - 1`, the corrected code and the loop invariant would be:

"p_value = is_sorted(arr[p->arr[len(arr)-1])"

However, since the code snippet is not correct, I'll provide the loop invariant for the standard insertion sort algorithm, which typically sorts the array in-place from the start:

"p_value = is_sorted(arr[0->arr[p-1])"

In this corrected invariant, `p_value` represents the property that the subarray `arr[0->arr[p-1]]` is sorted after `p` iterations of the outer loop. The index `p` is decremented in each iteration, effectively moving the boundary of the sorted subarray one element to the right."
